div.p: ANd if your Hawke be hard penned ≈øh√©e may bee drawne to be reclaimed: for while ≈øhe is tender penned, ≈øh√©e is not able to be reclaimed: and if ≈øhe b√©e a Go≈øhawke or Tercell, that is reclaymed, euer feede her with wa≈øht meate at the drawing and at the reclayming, but let it bee whot, and in this maner wa≈øh it: Put the meate into the water, and ≈øtrike it vp and downe in the water, and wring the water out of it, and feede her therwith, if ≈øhe be a Brauncher: and if it be an Eye≈ø≈øe, you mu≈øt wa≈øh it cleaner then ye doe to a Brauncher, and with a linnen cloath wipe it and feede her: and euermore the third day when ≈øhe is flying giue her ca≈øting, and if ≈øhee be a Go≈øhawke or Tercell in this manner: Take new Blanket cloath, and cut fiue mor≈øelles, and with a kniues poynt make a hole in euery mor≈øell, and put in the pellets of cloath, and put them in a faire di≈øh of water, then take the Hawke and giue her a mor≈øell of whote meate, the quantitie of halfe her ≈øupper, then take that which lyeth in the water and feede her for all night.

div.p: IF your Hawke bee a Sparhawke, euer feede her with vnwa≈øht meate, and looke that her ca≈øting bee plumage, then looke it be cleane vnder the Perch, and the next day you ≈øhall finde her ca≈øting vnder the Perch, and thereby you ≈øhall know whether ≈øh√©e be cleane or not: for ≈øome peece will be yellowe, and ≈øome greene, and ≈øome glamos and ≈øome cleare: and if it b√©e yeallowe ≈øhe ingendreth the frounce, which is an euill that will ri≈øe in the mouth, or in the cheeke: and if it bee gr√©ene ≈øh√©e ingendreth the rye: the condition of this euill is this, it will ari≈øe in the head and make the head ≈øwell, and in the eye glamos and darke, and if it bee not holpen it will fall downe into the legges and make them ranckle, and if it goe into the head againe, then the Hawke is lo≈øt, ≈øhe ingendreth an euil called the Cray, which is when ≈øhe may not muti≈øe.

div.p: FOr the Frounce in the mouth, take the ≈ømall end of a ≈øiluer ≈øpoone and put it into the fire, till it bee hot, then open the beake and burne the ≈øore, and annoynt it with the marrow of a Goo≈øe that hath lien long, and it will helpe her: if the frounce b√©e great, then there is a grube in it, which you mu≈øt cut with a Ra≈øer, holde the Hawke and ≈ølit the place where the ≈øore is, and you ≈øhall finde in it as it were the mawe of a Pigion, take a paire of ≈øheeres and ≈ønip the ≈øore, and make it as cleane as you can with a linnen cloath, and anoynt the ≈øore fower daies with Balme, and afterwards with Pampilion till it be whole: The frounce commeth when a man feedeth his Hawke with Porke or Hor≈øe fle≈øh foure daies together.

div.p: EVery third day let your Hawke bathe her during Sommer, if it b√©e faire weather, and once in a weeke in Winter, if it bee warme, and not els, and when you bathe your Hawke euer giue here ≈øome hote meate vnwa≈øhed, although ≈øh√©e bee a Go≈øhawke.

div.p:

div.p:

div.p: WHen your Hawke is troubled in her bowelles, you ≈øhall know it by her eyes, for her eyes will b√©e darke, and ≈øh√©e will looke drow≈øelie, and her muti≈øing will defile her fundament, then take Hawkes meate, and annoint it with the powder of Cauell, and giue it her to eat and ≈øhe ≈øhall be whole.

div.p: TAke yolkes of Egges rawe, when they b√©e well beaten together, put to it Spani≈øh Salt, and as much Honey, and wet therein thy Hawkes meate, and feed her therewith thr√©e daies together: and if ≈øhee make deintie in eating of it, then make her of force to ≈øwallow three or foure mor≈øelles a day, and pre≈øently ≈øhe ≈øhall be whole. div.p: VVHen you ≈ø√©e your Hawke to Nee≈øe and to ca≈øt water thorow her No≈øtriles, then doubtle≈ø≈øe ≈øh√©e is refrained, for this di≈øea≈øe take the greines of Chaflegre and of pepper, and grind it well and temper it with ≈øtrong vineger, and put it to the roufe of her mouth, and giue her fle≈øh to eate, and ≈øh√©e ≈øhall be whole.

div.p: TAke fayre Morfumum, and powder of Gilouer, and mingle them together and giue it her to eat, and if ≈øh√©e hold it pa≈øt the ≈øecond day, after ≈øhe ≈øhall be whole.

div.head: Proper tearmes v≈øed in keeping of Haukes.
div.p: AN Hawke tyreth, f√©edeth, gorgeth, beaketh, rou≈øeth, endueth, muteth, percheth, and iouketh, puketh ouer, proyneth, plumeth, ≈øh√©e warbeleth, and mantelleth: ≈øhe tyreth vpon rumpes, ≈øh√©e feedeth on al maner of fle≈øh: ≈øh√©e gorgeth when ≈øh√©e filleth her gorge full of meat: ≈øh√©e beaketh when ≈øhe ≈øueth, that is to ≈øay, when ≈øh√©e wipeth her beake: ≈øhee rou≈øeth when ≈øh√©e ≈øhaketh her feathers and her bodie together: ≈øh√©e endueth when the meate in her bowelles fall to di≈øge≈øtion: ≈øh√©e muteth when ≈øh√©e auoydeth her order: ≈øh√©e perches when ≈øhe ≈øtandeth on anie bow or Perch: ≈øh√©e iouketh when ≈øh√©e ≈øl√©epeth: ≈øh√©e puketh when ≈øhee auoydeth her meate out of her gorge into her bowelles: ≈øh√©e proyneth when ≈øh√©e fetcheth Oile ouer the taile and annoyneth her f√©ete and her feathers: ≈øh√©e plumeth when ≈øh√©e pulleth off the feathers of any Foule, or any thing, and ca≈øteth it from her: ≈øh√©e warbeleth when ≈øhe draweth her wings ouer the mid≈øt of her backe, and ≈øoftly ≈øhaketh them and letteth them fall againe: ≈øh√©e mantelleth when ≈øh√©e ≈øtretcheth out one wing alone, and afterward the other wing, and mo≈øt commonly ≈øhe doth that before ≈øhe warbleth her.

div.head: The names of Sparhawkes, as Ostregers and Speruiters haue determined.
div.p:
THere is a que≈øtion a≈øked whether a man ≈øhall call a Spere or a Sparrehawke, or an A≈øper Hawke, and O≈øtregers and Speruiters ≈øay, ≈øhee may bee called all three names: for the≈øe rea≈øons, ≈øh√©e may bee called a Sparrehawke: for of all Hawkes that there are, ≈øh√©e is mo≈øt ≈øpere that is to ≈øay, mo≈øt tender to k√©epe: For the lea≈øt mi≈øoieting and euill tending of her, killeth her, and ≈øh√©e may b√©e called an A≈øperre Hawke of ≈øharpne≈ø≈øe of her courage, and of her looking quicke, and al≈øo of her flying. Of all Hawkes ≈øhe may may bee called a Sparralike, for two rea≈øons: one is, ≈øh√©e ≈øpareth Go≈øhawkes and Tarcels vntill they time they b√©e reclaymed to flie, and till

Further, if that there were a ≈øhip fraught full of Hawkes: if there were but one Sparrehawke among≈øt them, there ≈øhould b√©e no cu≈øtome paid for anie of them, and therefore ≈øh√©e is in diuers re≈øpects a Sparhawke.

div.head: An Hawke flieth to the vewe, to the Beake, to the Toll, not a crewe, Ouerre, ferre Iutty.
div.p: AN Hawke flieth to the riuer diuers waies, and ≈øh√©e ≈øleyeth the foule diuer≈øly, that is to ≈øay, to the vew or to the beake, or the toll: and all is but one as ye ≈øhall vnder≈øtand hereafter. Sh√©e ≈øleieth al≈øo to the querre, to the cr√©epe, and no more waies but tho≈øe thr√©e, and ≈øh√©e nimmeth the foule at the ferre Iute, or at the Iuttie ferre.

div.head: Novv ye ≈øhall knovv the meaning of the≈øe tearmes, Randon, Creep, Emewed.
div.p: YOur Go≈øhawke or tercell that ≈øhall flie, to the vewe, to the toll, or to the beake: in this maner ≈øhe mu≈øt be taught. You mu≈øt find a Foule in the Riuer or in the Pitte, and ≈øet your Hawke a good ≈øpace from you vpon a Molehill, or vpon the ground, and creepe ≈øoftly to the foule, and when you come neere where the foule lieth, looke backward to the hawke, and with your hand becke your Hawke to come to you, and when ≈øh√©e is on wing, and commeth low by the ground, and is almo≈øt at you, then ≈ømite your tabre and crie huffe, huffe, huffe, and make the foule ≈øpring, and then the Hawke will nime her.

And now take h√©ede, if your Hawke nyme the foule at ferre ≈øide of the riuer, or at the pit from you, that ≈øh√©e ≈ølaie the foule at the ferre Iutte, and if ≈øhe ≈ølay it vpon that ≈øide ye bee on, as it may happe diuers times, then you ≈øhall ≈øay ≈øhe hath ≈ølaine the foule at the ferre Iutte. And if the Foule ≈øpring not but flie along after the Riuer and the Hawke nyme her, then ye ≈øhall ≈øay ≈øhe ≈ølew it at randon. And if your Hawke fleeth at or to the Creep, when you haue your Hawke on your fi≈øt, and that you cr√©epe ≈øoftly to the Riuer or to the pit, and ≈øtealeth to the brincke thereof, and then crie huffe, and then by that meane nyme the Foule, then ≈øh√©e is ≈ølaine at the Creep, at the ferre Iutte, or Iutte ferre: and if it happen, as it doth often, that the Foule for feare of your Hawke will ≈øpring and fall into the Riuer again, or ere the Hawke ≈ø√©e her, and ≈øo lie ≈øtill and dare not ari≈øe, then you ≈øhall ≈øay your Hawke hath renued the Foule into the Riuer, and there bee more Foules in the Riuer then your Hawke plumeth, and they dare not ari≈øe for feare of your Hawke.

div.head: A Theffe.
div.p: YOu ≈øhall vnder≈øtand that your Go≈øhawke mu≈øt not flie to the Riuer with belles in no wi≈øe: and therfore a Go≈øhawke is called a Theffe.

div.p: WHen your Hawke ≈ølieth to the Querre, when there bee in the ≈øtubbe time, Sardes of Mallards in the fielde, and when ≈øhe e≈øpieth them and commeth couert her ≈øelfe, and flie priuelie to the hedges or low by the ground, and nyme one of them ere they ri≈øe, then you may ≈øay that the Foule was ≈ølaine at the Querre.

div.p:

div.head: If you vvill make your Hawke to the Querre, you mu≈øt v≈øe her in this maner.
div.p: TAke a tame Mallarde and ≈øet him in a plaine field, and let him goe where he will, then ≈øet your Hawke vpon your fi≈øt, and goe to that plaine and hold vp your hand a pretie way off from the Mallard, and looke if your Hawke can e≈øpie it by her owne courage: and if ≈øh√©e haue found the Foule and de≈øire to flie to it, let her kill her, and plume well vpon her, and erue her ≈øo three or foure times, and then ≈øh√©e is made to the Querre.

I haue knowne Gentlemen that when they haue ≈øeene any tame Duckes, that if their Hawkes haue de≈øired to flie at them, they haue let them flie to the encouraging of them another time, and ≈øo haue wonne them to the Querre.

div.head: Of the Belles for Hawkes.
div.p:
LOoke that the Bells that your Hawke ≈øhall weare, that they b√©e not too heauie, nor that they be aboue her power to beare, and that they be not one heauier then an other, but that they bee both of a waight: al≈øo looke that they haue a good

Of Sparhawkes belles there is diuers choice, and little charge of them, for there is plentie of them: & for Go≈øhawkes, the belles of Millaine were coumpted the be≈øt, and they are verie good: for commonly they are ≈øounded with Siluer, and therefore they are ≈øould thereafter. div.head: A rare ≈øecret to catch foule, as Gee≈øe, Duckes, or Birds.
div.p: NVxe vomica, otherwaies called in Engli≈øh the Spring Nut, being a pretie deale of that ≈øod in a pecke of Barley, or as little as you thinke good, or Fetchis, or Wheate, and being ≈øtrowed where wild Gee≈øe or wild Duckes come, and as ≈øoone as they eate of this they will ≈øound, and you may take them will your hand. Al≈øo the powder of Nuxe vomica is good to kill Kites, Rauens, Pyes, Crowes, or anie other carronus foule. Al≈øo take a peece of fle≈øh and lay it in the fielde, and make holes in it, then put in the powder of Nuxe vomica in euery hole, and as ≈øoone as any foule eats of this, they will b√©e ouercome, and then they will fligh boult vpright, and fall downe to the ground ≈øtraight againe, and ≈øo you may take them.

div.head: Another pretie way to make birds dronke that you may take them with your hand.
div.p: TAke Wheat or Fitchis, or any other ≈ø√©ed, and lay the ≈øame in≈øteepe in lees of wine, or in the iuyce of Hemlock, and ≈øtrawe the ≈øame in the place where Birds v≈øe to haunt, and if they eat thereof, ≈øtraight waies they will b√©e ≈øo giddy, that you may take them with your hand.

div.head: An excellent good vvay to make a baite to catch vvild Gee≈øe, or wild Duckes, and all other ≈øort of foule.
div.p:
TAke the ≈øeed of Belenge, and the rootes al≈øo, and ≈øteepe them in water the ≈øpace of a day and a night: then ≈øeeth the ≈øaid ≈ø√©eds and roots in the water that they were ≈øt√©eped in, ≈øo that the ≈ø√©eds may well drinke & ≈øoke vp the water,
then lay the ≈øayd ≈øeedes or graine in the places where wilde Duckes and wilde Gee≈øe and woont to re≈øort, and they will eat this graine or ≈øeede ≈øo prepared, and thereupon will ≈øleepe as they were drunke, and in the meane time you may take them with your hands: but there mu≈øt be a pretie quantitie of this, e≈øpecially for wild Gee≈øe. This may al≈øo ≈øerue to take all other maner of foule that goe together in ≈øholes or companies. If you ≈øeeth this graine in Brim≈øtone, and lay it in the places where birds and foules are woont to feede, all that eate of it will fall downe and die: but to k√©epe them that they die not, you mu≈øt giue them to drinke Oyle Oliue, and ≈øhortly after they will reuiue againe. This is approued.

div.head: Of fouling with Limebu≈øh.
div.p: TO ≈øpeake of Limebu≈øh there can bee but little ≈øayd, for it is commonly knowne and practi≈øed of all both in Winter and Summer. In Winter it is v≈øed with Limebu≈øh, which we call Bat fouling, along by hedges to catch tho≈øe birds that re≈øt in hedges, one to carrie a light and another to beate the hedge: as al≈øo the Limebu≈øh is v≈øed at hou≈øe ends, Houels or Rickes: the Limebu≈øh is of little co≈øt, and is good for all times of the yeare. In Summer you may call Sparrowes with a whi≈øtle to your bu≈øh. There is another pretie way to catch birds with your Limebu≈øh, if you can get but an Oule & ≈øet her vpon an hedge, and ≈øet a bu≈øh of two by her of one ≈øide of her, & when the birds e≈øpie her they will flutter about her, and you ≈øhall catch good ≈øtore of Birds. In Winter you haue many other waies good.

div.head: How to foule vvith Nets.
div.p:
AL≈øo there is another manner of way to foule which is with Nets, but the v≈øe of them is in the night, and the darke≈øt night the better: and fir≈øt of fouling with Nets, which w√©e call in England mo≈øt commonly Birdbaiting, and ≈øome call it lowbelling, and the v≈øe of it is to goe with a great light of Cre≈ø≈øets, or ragges of linnen dipt in Tailow that will make
a good light, and you mu≈øt haue a panne of plate made like a Lanterne to carrie your light in, which mu≈øt haue a great ≈øocket to holde a great light, and carrie it before you on your brea≈øt with a Bell in your other hande of a great bigne≈ø≈øe, made in manner like to a Cowbel, but of greater bigne≈ø≈øe, and you mu≈øt ring it alwaies after one order, with two to goe with Nettes one of each ≈øide of him that carries the Bell, and what with the light that ≈øo doth ama≈øe them, and the Bell that ≈øo dooth a≈øtoni≈øh them, they will when you come neare them turne vp their white bellies, which you ≈øhall quicklie perceiue, then lay your Nets on them and take them: but the Bell mu≈øt not ≈øtint going: for if it cea≈øe, then the Birds wil flie vp if they heare anie more nigh. This is a good way to catch Larkes, Woodcockes, and Partriches, and all other land birds,

div.head: To goe vvith a Trammill.
div.p: TO goe a trameling with a Net it is a good way, for two may goe abroad with a Tramell and catch ≈øtore. You mu≈øt haue your Nette ≈øeauen yardes of length, and fiue in breadth, then take a couple of Poules or long roddes, ≈øo long as your Net is, and tie your poles to your Nettes all along the length of your Nettes, one of one ≈øide, and the other of the other ≈øide, then may you take your poule in your hand, and plucke out your poule out of breadth, and one goe in one thorow of the land and another in the other thorowe, and goe along in lands and carrie your Nette as farre forwards as you can, and when they heare you tread, then will they flutter vp into your Nette, which you ≈øhall quickly heare, then let downe your Nette to the ground, and gripe them, and take them from vnder your Nette, but if it be in a verie darke night, that you cannot ≈øee them, you ≈øhould haue a little cloa≈øe Lanterne, that one may perceiue no light, but when it is opened to ≈ø√©e to take them, but w√©e commonly make ≈øhift without.

div.head: To ≈øet Springes.
div.p: AL≈øo ≈øome v≈øe to ≈øet Springes, which is made with a running knot, and a ≈øticke in the ground to yerke vp with an other ≈øticke which the foule mu≈øt tread one, which is in manner like to a trop or running knot which is made of heares, which is good to bee ≈øet in fro≈øt time in ≈øprings for Woodcocks and Snipes, or any other foule if they come where that ≈øpringes bee ≈øet, or you may ≈øet them in Lands in the very thorowe for Woodcockes, where you know that they haunt, and in Summer you may ≈øet them in bu≈øhes either for Woodcocks or anie other birds, and you mu≈øt looke that the ≈øticke that they treade on bee ≈øomewhat round and browne, for if it b√©e white, they will feare to tread of it: and your nou≈øe mu≈øt be made of hor≈øe heare, and the blacker the better.

A breife Treatis of Fi≈øhing, with the art of Angling. Wherein is contained the perfect making of all maner of Implements appertaining to that exerci≈øe: the diuers and ≈øeuerall baytes for euery kind of Fi≈øh, with the be≈øt times of the yeare for the taking of them.

div.head: A briefe Treati≈øe of Fi≈øhing, with the Arte of Angling: wherein is conteined the perfect making of all manner of Implements appertaining to that exerci≈øe: The diuers and ≈øeuerall baites for euery kind of fi≈øh, with the be≈øt times of the yeere for the taking of them.
div.p: AS the wi≈øe man ≈øaith, a good ≈øpirit maketh a merie and flouri≈øhing age, and cau≈øeth a man to liue long: and truly in my opinion, the≈øe thr√©e thinges are a mede≈øine, and a pre≈øeruation for the ≈øame. The fir≈øt of them is, a merry thought. The ≈øecond is, labour not outragious. The third is, diet mea≈øurable. The fir≈øt, if a man will euermore b√©e in a merry thought, and haue a glad ≈øpirit, h√©e mu≈øt e≈øchewe all contrarious companie, and all places of debate, where hee may haue anie occa≈øion of melancholie, and hee mu≈øt e≈øchewe all places of Ryot, which is occa≈øion of ≈øurfit and ≈øickne≈ø≈øe, and hee mu≈øt drawe him to places of ≈øweete ayre, and eate nouri≈øhing meates and delectable.

As nowe I meane to de≈øcriue the≈øe di≈øportes and games, to finde the be≈øt of them as truely as I could, and although the right Noble and worthie Duke of Yorke, late mai≈øter of the game, hath de≈øcribed this arte of Fi≈øhing, and the re≈øt of the≈øe plea≈øures and di≈øportes. For hunting in myne opinion is labour≈øome, for the Hunt≈øman mu≈øt follow his hounds, ≈øweating full ≈øore, hee bloweth till his lips bli≈øter, and when h√©e thinkes hee hath a Hare, full oft it is a Hedgehog. Thus h√©e cha≈øeth vp and downe, and knoweth not ≈øometimes at what. He commeth home at night rayne beaten and pricked, and his clothes torne all to peeces, wet≈øhod and all myrie, and ≈øome of his
hounds lo≈øt, and ≈øome ≈øurbated. Such griefes and manie other happen vnto the Hunt≈ømen, which for di≈øplea≈øing of them that loue it I dare not report: thus truely mee thinketh it is not the be≈øt game and di≈øport of the foure.

Hawking is labourous and troubelous: for as often the Faulkner lo≈øeth his Hawkes, as the Hunter his Houndes, then is his game and di≈øport gone, yea, and full often hee crieth and whi≈øtleth, till he almo≈øt lo≈øeth his wind, his Hawke ≈øometime taketh aboue, and giueth no minde nor ≈øight to him: for when hee would haue her flie, then ≈øhee will bathe: with mi≈øf√©eding ≈øhee will haue the frounce, and many other di≈øea≈øes that bringeth to ≈øouce. Thus by proofe, this is not the be≈øt di≈øport and game of the ≈øayd foure. In my opinion the game of Fouling is the ≈øimple≈øt: for in Winter in cold weather, the Fouler can doe no good, but in the harde≈øt and colde≈øt weather, which is greeuous: for when he would goe to his ginnes, hee cannot for colde: manie a deui≈øe hee maketh, and yet in the morning his fortune is hard, when hee is wet vp to the wa≈øte. Manie di≈øcommodities I could ≈øhewe, but for offending I let them pa≈ø≈øe. Then ≈øith it is ≈øo, that Hawking, Hunting, and Fouling bee ≈øo laborous, that none of them may bee a meane to a merrie ≈øpirit, which is the cau≈øe of long life, vnto the ≈øayings of the wi≈øe in his Parables: doubtle≈ø≈øe then it mu≈øt followe, that fi≈øhing with the Angle is mo≈øt delectable, for all other are trouble≈øome and laberous: For in ≈øome kinde of fi≈øhing it maketh the Fi≈øher through wet and ≈øo colde, that many and ≈øundrie times there in≈øueth diuers infirmities through the ≈øame: But the Angler hee hath no colde, no di≈øea≈øe, no impediment, except it bee through him≈øelfe: for hee can lo≈øe but a Line or a Hooke at the mo≈øt, which hee may make againe at his owne lei≈øure, as he ≈øhall be taught hereafter: So then is not his lo≈ø≈øe greeuous if the fi≈øh breake away with his Hooke, that is the mo≈øt: for and he faile of one, hee hitteth of another: and if hee quite faile, yet hee hath his whole≈øome walkes, his plea≈øant ≈øhades, the ≈øweete ayre, the excellent ≈ømelles of the ≈øweete
Medowe flowers, which maketh him hungrie: hee heareth the melodious Harmonie of Birdes and other Foules, which hee thinketh is better then the noi≈øe of Hounds, the bla≈øt of Horns, or all the cry that Hunters, Faulkners, or Foulers can make: and if the Angler doe take fi≈øh, then hath h√©e a mercy ≈øpirit, and a glad heart. But who ≈øo will v≈øe this exerci≈øe, hee mu≈øt ri≈øe carely, which is profitable to man for the health of his bodie: For as the olde Engli≈øh Prouerbe is, who ≈øo dooth ri≈øe carely ≈øhall be holie, healthie, and happie. Thus I haue ≈øhewed in this Treati≈øe, that this di≈øport and game of Angling, is the very meane to induce a man to a merrie ≈øpirit. And to the content of all tho≈øe that haue delight in the≈øe exerci≈øes, I haue collected this Treati≈øe following, which you may v≈øe at your plea≈øure.

IF you will bee perfite in this art of Angling, you mu≈øt fir≈øt learne to make your Implements: that is to ≈øay, your Rod, and your Lines of diuers colours: This done, you mu≈øt know how you mu≈øt angle, and in what place of the water, how d√©ep, and at what time of the day, and for what maner of Fi≈øh, and what weather, how many impediments there be in fi≈øhing, and ≈øpeciallie in Angling, and what baite belongeth to euerie fi≈øh euerie time of the yeare: And how you ≈øhall make your baites breede, where you ≈øhall finde them, and how you ≈øhall keepe them for the mo≈øt part: How you ≈øhall make your Hookes of Steele, and of O≈ømonde, ≈øome for the Dub, ≈øome for the Flote, and for the ground. And here I will teach you how you ≈øhall make your Rod: you ≈øhall cut it betweene Michalmas and Candlemas, of an ell and a halfe long, beeing the arme of a great Ha≈øell, Willow, or A≈øpe, and beth him in a whote Ouen, and ≈øet it euen and ≈øtraight, and let it cole a moneth, then take a corde and bind it fa≈øt about, and binde it to a fourme or to a peece of ≈øquare timber: then take a Plummers wyer that is euen and ≈øtreight, and ≈øharpe the one ende and heate it in the fire and Charcole, and burne the hole quite through in the pith,
beginning at both endes and goe on too the middle: you may burne the hole with a Bird broch, but let the la≈øt broch b√©e bigger then any of them before, then let it lie and coole two daies, vnbinde it and let it lie in the ≈ømoke, or the roufe of a hou≈øe, till it bee through drie. In the ≈øame ≈øea≈øon cut a yard of greene Ha≈øell, and beth it euen and ≈øtraigh, and let it drie with the ≈øtaffe: and when it is drie make it fit for the hole in the ≈øtaffe, vnto the halfe length of the ≈øtaffe: and to fill the other halfe of the crop, take a faire ≈øhute of Black thorne, Crab tree Medler, or els of Iuniper, cut in the ≈øame ≈øea≈øon, and well bethed and ≈øtraight, and ≈øet them fit together, ≈øo that the crop may enter all into the ≈øayde hole, then ≈øhaue your ≈øtaffe and make it Tapar wi≈øe, then hoope the ≈øtaffe at both endes with long hoopes of yron, or latten after the cleanlie≈øt maner, and a pike in the nether end fa≈øtened with a running wyer to take in and out of your ≈øtaffe, and ≈øet your crop a handfull within your vpper end of your ≈øtaffe, in ≈øuch wi≈øe that it bee as biggethere as in anie other place aboue, then arme your ≈øtaffe downe to the fret with a Line of ≈øixe heares, and dubble the Line and fret it fa≈øt on with a peece of a bowe: And thus you ≈øhall make you a ≈øtaffe to walke with, and no man may knowe whether you haue ≈øuch Implements about you: It will b√©e very light and nimble to fi≈øh with at your plea≈øure, and is alwaies very ready and nece≈ø≈øarie.

AFter you haue thus made your Rod, you mu≈øt learne to colour your Lines of heare after this manner. You mu≈øt take of a white Hor≈øe taile the longe≈øt heares you can get, and the bigger and rounder it is, the better it is, depart them in ≈øixe parts, and colour euery part by him≈øelfe in diuers colours: as yeallowe, greene, tawnie, browne, ru≈ø≈øet, or du≈økie colour: And for to make your heare take a good creene colour, you mu≈øt take a quart of Ale, and put into it halfe a pound of Allom, and put your heare and all together in a little pan, and let them boyle ≈øofly halfe an hower, then take out your heare
and let them drie, then take a pottle of faire water, and put it into a pan, and two handfulles of Wexen, and pre≈ø≈øe it with a Tyle ≈øtone, and let it boyle ≈øoftly the ≈øpace of an hower: and when it is yeallowe on the ≈økumme, put therein your heares, with halfe a pound of Copperous beaten into powder, and let it boyle the ≈øpace of going of halfe a mile, and then ≈øet it downe and let it coole the ≈øpace of fiue or ≈øixe howers, then take out the heare and drie it, and it will b√©e the be≈øt greene for the water that can bee, and the more that you put of Copperous to it the better it will be.

div.head: For to make your heare yeallowe.
div.p: DRe≈ø≈øe it as before with Allom, and after with Oldes, or Waxen, with Copperous or Verdigreace.

div.head: To make another yeallow.
div.p: TAke a pottle of ≈ømall Ale, and ≈øtampe thereinto three handfulles of Walnut leaues, and put it together, and then put in your heare that it be as d√©epe as you will haue it.

div.head: For to make Ru≈ø≈øet heare.
div.p: TAke a pint of ≈øtrong L√©e, and halfe a pound of Sote, and a little Iuice of Walnut leaues, and a quart of Allom, put them altogether in a Pan, and boile them well, and when it is cold put in your heare till it be as darke as you will haue it.

div.head: To make your heare browne.
div.p: TAke ≈øtrong Ale and Sault, and mingle them together, and put your heares two daies and two nights and they will bee a perfect colour.

div.head: For to make a tawny colour.
div.p: TAke Lime and water, and put them together, and then put your heares therein foure or fiue houres, then take them out, and put them into a Tanners O≈øe one day, and it will be as fine a tawny colour as can be for your purpo≈øe.

The ≈øixt part of your heare, you ≈øhall keepe ≈øtill white for
lines, for the double hooke to fi≈øh for the Trout, & for ≈ømall lines to lie for the Roche and the Dace.

When your heare is thus collected, you mu≈øt knowe for which waters and which ≈øea≈øons they ≈øhall ≈øerue, the greene cullour for all cleare waters from Aprill vntill September. The yellowe cullour in euery cleare water from September to Nouember. For it is like the Weedes and other kinde of gra≈ø≈øe that is broken in the Riuer. The ru≈ø≈øet cullour ≈øerueth all the Winter vntill the ende of Aprill, as well in Riuers as in Pooles or lakes.
The browne cullour ≈øerueth for the water that is blacki≈øh, in Riuers or other waters: the tawny cullours, for tho≈øe riuers or waters that be heathy or mori≈øh.

Now you mu≈øt make your lines after this order. Fir≈øt you mu≈øt haue an in≈øcrument for the twi≈øting of your line. Take your heare and cut off a handfull at the ende, becau≈øe it is not ≈øtrong enough, then turne the top to the tayle ouer each alike, and make it into three parts, and knit euerie part by him≈øelfe, and knit the other end altogether: then put that end fa≈øt into your in≈øtrument into the clift, and make it fa≈øt with a wedge, fower fingers ≈øhorter then your heare, then twine your warpe one way alike, and fa≈øten them in three cliftes alike ≈øtraight, then take that out at the other end, and let it twine that way that it de≈øireth, then ≈øtreine it a little, and knit it for vndoing, and that is good.

So when you haue ≈øo manie links as will ≈øuffice for a line to make it long enough, then mu≈øt you knit them together with a water knot, or a Dutch knot, and when your knot is knit, cut of the voyde ≈øhore endes a ≈øtrawe breadth from the knot, thus ≈øhall your lines be fayre and euen: and al≈øo ≈øure for any maner of Fi≈øh.

The fine≈øt practi≈øe is in making your hockes, and for the making of them you may haue your ≈øeuerall kinde of tooles that you may doe them artificiallie. A ≈øemy clam of yron, a bendor, a payre of long and ≈ømall tongues, and a knife ≈øomewhat
hard and thicke, an Anuild, and a little hammer.

And for a ≈ømall Fi≈øh you ≈øhall take the ≈ømalle≈øt quarrell Needles that you can find of Steele: and you ≈øhall put the Quarrell in a fyre of Charcole till it bee of the ≈øame cullour that the fire is, then take it out and lay it to coole, and you ≈øhall find it well alayd to file, then ray≈øe the beard with your knife, and make the poynt ≈øharpe, then alay him againe or el≈øe hee will breake in the bending, then bend him as h√©e will ≈øerue for your purpo≈øe, you ≈øhall make them of great Needles, as ≈øhoomakers Needles, Taylers needles, or imbroderers Needles: but looke that they will bowe at the point or els they bee not good, and when you haue beaten flat the end of the hooke, fyle him ≈ømooth that it fret not the line, the put it into the fire, and giue it an ea≈øie red heat, then ≈øuddainly quench it in water, and it will b√©e hard and ≈øtrong. And for to haue knowledge of your In≈øtruments that bee nece≈ø≈øarie, without the which you are not able to accompli≈øh your de≈øire, that is, your Hammer, Knife, Pyn≈øon, Claem, Wedge, File, Wre≈øt, and a Needle.

When you haue made your hookes, then you mu≈øt ≈øet them on according to their ≈øtrength and greatne≈ø≈øe. Fir≈øt take ≈ømall red ≈øilke, and if it bee for a great hooke then double it and twi≈øt it, and for a ≈ømall hooke let it be ≈øingle, and therewith fret the line where as you will haue the hooke ≈øtand, a ≈øtrawe breadth, then ≈øet to your hooke and fret it with the ≈øame thred the two partes, of the length that it ≈øhall bee fret in all, and when you come to the third part, then turne the end of your line vp again double, to the other third part, then put your thred in at the hole twi≈øe or thri≈øe, and let it goe each time about the yeard of your hooke: then wette the hooke and drawe, and looke that your line lie euermore within your hookes, and not without, and then cut of the lines end, and the thred as nigh as you can, ≈øauing the fret.

So, yee knowe with how great Hookes you ≈øhall angle to euery fi≈øh, now I will tell with how many heares you ≈øhall
angle for euerie fi≈øh. Fir≈øt for the Menowe with a line of one heare: For the waring Roche, the Bleake, the Gogion, and the Ruffe, with a line of three heares: For the Dace and the Roch, with a line of three heares: For the Pearch, the Flounder, and Bremet, with a line of foure heares: For the Cheuin, the Breame, the Tench, and the Eele, with ≈øixe heares: For the Troute, and the gra≈øing Barble, and the great Cheuin, with nine heares: For the great Troute with twelue heares: For the Salmon, with fifteene heares: and for a Pyke with a chalke line made in the colour afore≈øayd, armed with a line, as you ≈øhall heare hereafter. When I ≈øpeake of the Pyke, your Lines mu≈øt bee plumed with lead, and the neare≈øt plumbe to the Hooke, bee a foote of at the lea≈øt, and euery plumbe of the quantitie of the bigne≈ø≈øe of the line: There be thr√©e maner of plumbes, for a ground line, renning, and for the ≈ølote: ≈øet vpon the ground line lying, ten plumbs all ioyning together on the ground line, renning, nine or ten ≈ømall: the flote plumbe ≈øhall be heauie, that the fir≈øt plucke of any fi≈øh may pull it into the water, and make your plumbes round and ≈ømooth, that they ≈øticke not on ≈øtones and w√©edes.

THen you ≈øhall make your ≈ølotes in this manner. Take a peece of a Corke that is cleane without holes, and bore it through with a ≈ømall hote yron, and put thereinto a quill or pen euen and ≈øtraight: alwaies note that the greater the hole, the bigger the pen, and ≈øhape it great in the midde≈øt, and ≈ømall at both ends, and e≈øpeciallie ≈øharpe in the nether end, and make them ≈ømooth on a Grind≈øtone, and looke that the flote for one heare be no bigger then a Peas, for two hears as a Beame, for twelue heares as a Walnut, and ≈øo euery line mu≈øt haue according to his portion. Al maner of lines that be not for the ground, mu≈øt haue flotes: & the renning ground line mu≈øt haue a flote, and the lying ground line mu≈øt haue a flote.

NOw I haue taught you to make your heares, hereafter I meane to ≈øhewe you the art of Angling. You ≈øhall vnder≈øtand
that there is ≈øixe manner of Anglings: the one is at the ground for the Troute, and other fi≈øh: another is at the ground at the Arch or ≈øtang where it ebbeth and floweth, for Bleake, Roch, and Dace: the third is with a flote for all maner of fi≈øh: the fourth, with a Menowe for the Troute without plumbe or flote: the fift is renning in the ≈øame for the Roche and Dace with two heares or one heare, and a flie: the fixt is a dubbed hocke for the Troute or Grayling. And for the fir≈øt and principall poynt in Angling, looke that you keepe you from the ≈øight of the fi≈øh, either ≈øtande clo≈øe on the land, or behinde ≈øome bu≈øh: for if h√©e ≈ø√©e you, then your ≈øport is marde for he will not bite, and looke that you ≈øhadowe not the water as little as you can, for it is that which will make him be gone: for if the fi≈øh b√©e fraide h√©e will not bite a good while after. For all manner of fi≈øh that feede by grounde, you mu≈øt angle for them to the bottome, ≈øo that your hooke ≈øhall runne and lie on the ground: and for all other fi≈øh that feedeth aboue, you ≈øhall angle for them at the midde≈øt of the water, or aboue the mid≈øt, or belowe the midde≈øt whether ye will, for the greater the fi≈øh, the nearer he lieth to the bottome of the water, and euermore the ≈ømaller the fi≈øh, the more he ≈øwimmeth aboue. The third good poynt, is when the fi≈øh biteth, that you be not too ha≈øtie to ≈ømite nor to take: for you mu≈øt abide till the bayte bee farre in the mouth of the fi≈øh, and then tarrie no longer, and this is for the ground: and for the flote when you ≈øee it pulled into the water, or els caried ≈øoftly vpon the water, then ≈ømite, and looke that you neuer ouer-≈ømite the ≈øtrength of your line for breaking: And if it be your fortune to ≈ømite a great fi≈øh with a ≈ømal line, then you mu≈øt leade him in the water, and labour him there till he b√©e drowned and ouercome, then take him as well as you can, and euer take heede that you ≈øtreyne him not ouer the ≈øtrength of your line, and as much as you can let him not goe pa≈øt your lines ende from you, but keepe him euer vnder your Rod, and holde him as ≈øtreight as your line will ≈øu≈øtain, and beare his leapes and his plunges as well as you can with
your Crope in your hand.

div.head: Here I will declare vnto you, in what place of the vvater you ≈øhall angle, either in Poole or ≈øtanding water, & according to the deepenes of the ≈øaid water.
div.p: THere is no great diuer≈øitie in anie place of a Poole, ≈øo it b√©e deepe, for it is a pri≈øon to all fi≈øhes, and therefore the ≈øooner taken: but in the Riuer the be≈øt angling is where it is deepe, and cleare by the ground, as grauell or clay without mud or weedes, and e≈øpecially if there bee any whirling in the water, or a couert, as a hollowe bancke or great rootes of Trees, or long weedes fleeting aboue the waters, where the fi≈øh may hide them≈øelues at certaine times when they li≈øt. Al≈øo it is good to angle in ≈øtiffe ≈øtreames, and al≈øo in vallies of waters, and in flood gates, and Mill pits, and at the bancke where the ≈øtreame runneth, and is deepe and cleare by the ground, and in any place where the fi≈øh haunt and haue any feeding.

Now you ≈øhall vnder≈øtand the be≈øt time of the yeere, and the be≈øt times of the day, from the beginning of May to September: the be≈øt time of their baiting is from foure a clocke in the morning vntill eight a clocke, and from foure in the after noone till eight at night: but it is not ≈øo good in the afternoone as in the morning: and if it b√©e a cold winde and a lowring day it is much better then a cleare day, and the Poole fi≈øhes will bite be≈øt in the morning.

And if you ≈øee at anie time of the day the Trout or the Grayling leape, angle for him with a dub according to the ≈øea≈øon of the yeare, and where the water ebbeth and floweth: the fi≈øh wil bite in ≈øome place at the ebbe, and in ≈øome place at the flood, after they haue had re≈øting behind Stanges and Arches of Bridges, and other ≈øuch places.

The principall time to angle is in a lowring day, when the winde bloweth ≈øoftly: for in Summer when it is verie whote then it is naught: from September vntill Aprill in a fayre Sunnie day, it is very good angling, and if the winde at that
time haue anie parte of the Orient weather, then it is naught: and when it is a great winde & that it ≈ønoweth, raineth, or haileth, or is a great tempe≈øt, as Thunder or Lightning, or a ≈øwollie hot weather, then it is naught for to angle.

You ≈øhall further vnder≈øtand that there be twelue empediments, which cau≈øe a man to take no fi≈øh, as it doth mo≈øt commonly hap. The fir≈øt is if that your harne≈ø≈øe be not fit and well made. The ≈øecond is if your baites be not good and fine. The third is, if you angle not in biting time. The fourth is, if the fi≈øh be fraid with the ≈øight of man. The fift, if the water be red, thick, and white, of any floud lately fallen: the ≈øixt, if the Fi≈øh ≈øtirre not for cold: the ≈øeuenth, if the weather be hote: the eight, if it raine: the ninth, if it haile or ≈ønow: the tenth, if it ibe a tempe≈øt: the eleuent, if it be a great wind: the twelfth is, if the wind be in the Ea≈øt, and that is wor≈øt, for commonly neither in winter nor ≈øommer the fi≈øh will not bite if it bee in the Ea≈øt, the We≈øt or the North is good, but the South is be≈øt of all.

And now I haue taught you to make your harne≈ø≈øe, and how you ≈øhall fi≈øh therewith in all pointes. Now there re≈øteth to ≈øhew you what baites be be≈øt for euery kind of fi≈øh, for all times and ≈øea≈øons of the yeare, which is the principall part of this art: without the knowledge of which baites, al the re≈øt before were to no purpo≈øe: for there is no man can take the fi≈øh to ≈øwallow the hooke without the bait, and therefore I haue ≈øet you downe euery Fi≈øh with his proper baite belonging to the time, and the be≈øt time to catcht them as followeth.

div.head: And becau≈øe the Sammon of all fi≈øh is the mo≈øt ≈øtatelie≈øt, therefore I meane to begin with him the fir≈øt.
div.p:
THe Sammon is a very gentle fi≈øh, but hee is trouble≈øome to take, for commonly he is in deepe places of great Riuers, and for the mo≈øt part hee will keepe him in the midde≈øt of it, that you may not come at him, and he is in ≈øea≈øon from March, vntill Michaelmas: in which ≈øea≈øon you may angle for him, with the≈øe baytes if you can get them. Fir≈øt with a red worme in the beginning and ending of the ≈øea≈øon, and al≈øo with a grub
that br√©edeth in a dounghill, and e≈øpecially there is a ≈øoueraine baite that breedeth in a water Docke, and he biteth not at the ground, but at the flote, you may take him when hee leapeth in like maner as doth a Trout or a Grailing, and the≈øe are proued baites for the Samon.

The Trout becau≈øe h√©e is a daintie Fi≈øh, and al≈øo a verie feruent byter: hee is the next that I meane to ≈øhewe you the time to catch him. From March vntill Michalmas h√©e lieth on the grauell, and in a ≈øtreame you may angle for him with a line, lying or running, ≈øauing in leaping time, and then with a dub, and early with a running ground line, and in the day time with a flote line. You ≈øhall angle for him in March, with a Menowe hanging on your hooke, by the nethernes without Flote or Plumbe, drawing vp and downe the ≈øtreame till you feele him fa≈øt. Al≈øo it is good to angle for him with ground lines, and with a red worme, for the mo≈øt part, and in Aprill take the ≈øame baytes, as al≈øo the Canker that br√©edeth in a great tree, and the red ≈ønaile, you may take the bob worme vnder the Cowtord and the ≈øilke worme, and the bayte that breedeth on a Fearne leafe. In Iune take a red worme and nippe of his head, and a cod worme, and put it on the hooke. In Iuly take the Codworme, and the red worme together. In Augu≈øt take a fle≈øh flie, and the fat of Bacon, and bind them together about the hooke. In September take the red worme and the Menowe. In October take the ≈øame. There bee ≈øpecially for the Troute all times of the yeare. From Aprill vntill September the Troute leapeth: then angle for him with a dubbed hooke according to the mouth: which dubbed hookes you ≈øhall finde in the ende of this Treati≈øe, and the mouthes with them.

The Grayling of ≈øome ≈øo called, of others Vmbre, It is a right delicate fi≈øh to mans mouth, and you may take him as you doe the Troute, and the≈øe are his baytes. In March and in Aprill the red worme, in May the green worme, a little brai≈øed worme, the docke canker, and the Hawthorne worme. In
Iune the bayte that breedeth betweene the Barke of an Oke. In Iuly a bait that breedeth on the Fearne leafe, and the great red worme, and nip off the head and put it on the hooke, and a Codworme before. In Augu≈øt the red worm and a dock worm, and all the yeare after a worme.

The Barbell is a ≈øweet fi≈øh, but he is a very quey≈øie meat, and verie daungerous to eate: for commonly hee bringeth an inconuenience to the Febres, and if he be eaten raw, he may be the cau≈øe of a mans death, which hath oftentimes b√©ene ≈ø√©ene, and the≈øe are his baites in March and in Aprill. Take fre≈øh Chee≈øe, and lay it on a Trencher, and cut it into ≈ømall peeces, the length of your hooke, then take a Candle and burne it on your hooke till it bee yellowe, and then bind it on you hooke with Fletchers Silke, and make it rough like a Welbede, this baite is good all the Sommer ≈øea≈øon. In may and in Iune take the Hawihorne Worme, and the great red Worme, and nip the head off, and put a codworme on your hooke before, and this is a verie good baite. In Iuly take the red worme for the chiefe, and the Hawthorne, together with the waterdocke leafe worme. In Augu≈øt, and for all the yeare, take the tallowe of a ≈øheepe, and of ≈øoft chee≈øe, eache of them alike, and a little Hony, and temper them together till they b√©e tough, and then put a little Flower into it, and make it in ≈ømall pellets, and that is a good bayte to Angle with at the ground, and looke that it ≈øinke in the water, or els it is not good for that purpo≈øe.

The Carpe is a deyntie fi≈øh, but there is no great plentie of them, and therefore I write lea≈øt of him, but he is a verie ≈øubtile fi≈øh to take, for he√©e is ≈øo ≈øtrong in the mouth that there is no weake harnes will hold him: and as touching his baites I haue little knowledge thereof, and therefore I would be loth to write more then I know and haue proued: but I am ≈øure the red worm, and the Menow are good baites for him at all times, as I haue heard diuers good Fi≈øhers report.

The Cheuin is a ≈øtately fi≈øh, and his head is a deinty mor≈øell, there is no fi≈øh ≈øo ≈øtrongly enarmed on the bodie with
≈øcales, and becau≈øe he is a ≈øtrong biter he hath the more baites, which are the≈øe: In March, the red worme at the ground: for commonly then he will bite there at all times of the yeare, if he be anie thing hungrie: In Aprill, the Canker that br√©edeth in the tree, the worme that breedeth betweene the barke of the tree of Oke, the red worme, and the young Fro≈øhes when the feete be cut off: al≈øo the Stone flye, the Bob vnder the Cowturd, the red Snaile: In May, the baite that breedeth in the Ozier leafe, and the Docke canker put on the hooke, and a baite that breedeth on the Fearne leafe, the Redworme, and the baite that groweth vpon the Hawthorne, and a baite that br√©edeth on the Oke leafe, and a Silke worme and a Codworme together: In Iune, take the Creker and the Dorre, al≈øo a red worme the head beeing cut off, and a Codworme before, and put them on the hooke: al≈øo a Grub that br√©edeth in the dunghill, a great Gre≈øhopper, and the Humble bee in the Medowe: Al≈øo young Bees and Hornets, and the flie that is among the Pi≈ømiers hils. In Augu≈øt, take Wort wormes, and Maggots, till Michalmas. In September, the red worme, and a young Mou≈øe not heared, and the Hou≈øe combe.

The Breame is a noble fi≈øh and a deyntie, and you ≈øhall angle for him from March vntill Augu≈øt with a red Worme, and then with a Butterflie, and with a baite that groweth among≈øt greene Reede, and a baite that breedeth in the barke of a dead tree: and for Bremets take Maggots, and from that time forward all the yerre take the red worme: and in the Riuer, browne bread.

The Tench is a good fi≈øh, and healeth in a maner all other fi≈øh that b√©e hurt, if they may come to him, h√©e is mo≈øt partes of the yeare in the mud, and ≈øtirreth mo≈øt in Iune and Iuly, and in other ≈øea≈øon but little, he is an euill biter, and his baites bee the≈øe: For all the yeare, browne bread to≈øted with Honney, the likene≈ø≈øe of a bantred loafe, and the great red wore, and take the blacke blood in the heart of a Sheepe, and flower and hony, and temper them all together, ≈øo make them ≈øofter then pa≈øt,
and annoint the red worme therewith, both for this fi≈øh and for others, and they will bite much the better thereat all times of the yeare.

The Pearch is a deyntie fi≈øh, and pa≈ø≈øing whole≈øome, and a great and earne≈øt biter: In march, the red worme, the Bob vnder the Cowturde. In Aprill and May, the Slowthorne, worme, and the Codworme. In Iune, the bait that breedeth in an old fallen Oke, and the great Canker. In Iuly the bait that breedeth on the Ozier leafe, and the Bob that breedeth on the dunghill, and the Hawthorne worme, and the Codworme. In Augu≈øt, the red worme and Maggots, and all the yeare after take the red worme for the be≈øt.

The Roch is an ea≈øie fi≈øh to take, and if he be fat and penned then is hee good meate, and his baites are the≈øe. In March take the red worme. In Aprill, the Bob vnder the Cowturde. In May, the baite that breedeth in the Oken leafe, and the Bob on the dunghill. In Iune, the baite that breedeth on the Ozier, and the Codworme. In Iuly, the Hou≈øe ≈øpies, and the baite that breedeth on an Oke, and the Notworme, and Mathewes maggots, vntill Michalmas, and after that the fat of Bakon.

The Dace is a gentle Fi≈øh, and is verie good meate, in March his haite is a red worme, and in Aprill the Bob vnder the Cowtord. In May the docke cancker, and the bayte on the Slowthorne and that on the Oken leafe. In Iune the Codworme and the baite on the Ozier, and the white Grub on the dunghill. In Iuly take hou≈øe ≈øpies, and the flies that breede in Pi≈ømyre hils, the Codworm and Magots till Michaelmas, and if the water be cleare, you ≈øhall take fi≈øh when other ≈øhall take none, and from that time forth do as you would do for the Roch: for commonly their biting and baites be alike.

The bleake is but a feeble fi≈øh, yet is he hol≈øome. His baite from March till Michaelmas b√©e the ≈øame that I haue written for the Roche and the Dace, ≈øauing all the ≈øommer you may angle for him with a hou≈øe flie, and in Winter ≈øea≈øon with
Bacon, and with other baites as hereafter you ≈øhall learne.

The Ruffe is a very good and a hol≈øome fi≈øh, and a fr√©e biter: but ≈øubtill withall, and you mu≈øt angle for him with the ≈øame baites and the ≈øame ≈øea≈øons of the yeare as I haue tolde you of the Pearch: for they b√©e like in fi≈øh and f√©eding, ≈øauing the Ruffe is le≈ø≈øe, and therefore you mu≈øt haue the ≈ømaller baytes.

The Flounder is a hol≈øome fi≈øh and fr√©e, but a ≈øubtill byter, in this manner: for commonly when he ≈øucketh his meate, h√©e feedeth at the ground, and therefore you mu≈øt angle for him with a ground line lying, and h√©e hath but one manner of bayt, and that is a red worme, and that is mo≈øt chiefe for all manner of Fi≈øh.

The Gogin is a good fi≈øh of his bigne≈ø≈øe, and he biteth well at the ground, and his baites for all the yeare is the red worme, Codworme and Magots, and you mu≈øt angle for him with a flote, and let your baite bee neare the bottome, or els vpon the ground.

The Menowe when h√©e ≈øhineth in the water is bitter, and though his bodie bee but little, yet h√©e is a rauenous biter and eger, and you ≈øhall angle for him with the ≈øame baites that you doe for the Gogion, ≈øauing they mu≈øt be ≈ømall.

The Eele is a que≈øie fi≈øh, and a rauenor and a deuourer of the broode of fi≈øh, and the Pike is al≈øo a deuourer of fi≈øh, I put them both behind all other fi≈øh for to angle. For the Eele, you ≈øhall find the hole in the ground of water, and it is blewe and blacki≈øh, there put in your hooke till it bee a foot within the hole, and your bait ≈øhall be a great angle with a Menowe.

The Pyke is a good fi≈øh, but that h√©e is a deuourer of all fi≈øh a≈øwell of his owne broode as of other, and therefore I loue him the wor≈øe: and for to take him ye ≈øhall doe thus. Take a Rock or a fre≈øh Herring, and a wyer with a hooke in the end, and put it in at the mouth and downe by the ridge to the taile of the Herring, and then put the line of your hooke in after, and draw the hooke into the cheeke of the fre≈øh Herring, then
put a plumbe of leade on your line a yarde from your booke, and a flote in the midway betweene, and ca≈øt it in a pit where the Pykes v≈øe, and this is the be≈øt and ≈øure≈øt way to take: and thr√©e manner of taking of him there is. Take a Fro≈øh, and put it on your hooke betweene the ≈økinne and the bodie in at the necke, on the backe halfe, and put on the flote a yard thereto, and ca≈øt it where the Pyke haunteth, and you ≈øhall haue him. Another way: Take the ≈øame baite and put it in ≈øafe tied, and ca≈øt it into the water with a Corke, and you ≈øhall not faile of him: And if you minde to haue good ≈øport, then tie your cord to a Goo≈øe foot, and you ≈øhall ≈øee good haling betweene the Goo≈øe and the Pyke, who ≈øhall haue the hetter.

Now you knowe with what baites and in what ≈øea≈øons of the yeare you ≈øhall angle for euery kinde of fi≈øh, now I meane to tell you how you ≈øhall keepe and feede your quicke baites. You ≈øhall keepe them all in generall and euerie one ≈øeuerall by him≈øelfe, with ≈øuch things as they are bred in, and as long as they be quicke and newe they be fine: but when they be in a ≈ølough or dead, then they are nought: Out of the≈øe b√©e excepted three broodes: that is, Hornets, Humble b√©es and Wa≈øpes, which you ≈øhall bake in bread, and dip their heades in blood, and let them drie. Al≈øo except Maggots, which when they bee bred great with their naturall feeding, you ≈øhall feede them furthermore with Sheepes tallowe, and take heede that in going about your di≈øports you open no mans gates, but that you ≈øhut them againe. Al≈øo you ≈øhall not v≈øe this ≈øport craftelie for couetou≈øne≈ø≈øe, to the increa≈øing and ≈øparing of your money only, but principally for your ≈øolace, and for the maintenance of your bodily health. For when you purpo≈øe to goe on your di≈øports in fi≈øhing, you will not de≈øire greatly manie per≈øons with you, which might let you of your game, and then your minde may bee well giuen to the ≈øeruing of God, as in prayer or otherwi≈øe, and in ≈øo doing you ≈øhall e≈øchewe and auoyde manie vices, as Idlene≈ø≈øe, which is the principall leader to vice, and it is commonly ≈ø√©ene that it bringeth diuers
to their vtter de≈øtruction. Al≈øo you mu≈øt not bee too de≈øirous of your game but with di≈øcretion, that you marre not other mens game and your owne too, as too much at one time, which you may lightly doe, if in euery poynt you fulfill this pre≈øent treati≈øe: but when you haue a ≈øufficient me≈ø≈øe, to content your ≈øelfe for that time. Al≈øo you ≈øhall apply your ≈øelfe to the nouri≈øhing of the gaine, and in de≈øtroying of ≈øuch thinges as ≈øhall be the deuourers of it.
